lines.text:
[Kinder has just finished a psychiatric evaluation of Reisman's troops]
So what does that give you?

Doesn't give me anything. But along with these other results, it gives *you* just about the most twisted, anti-social bunch of psychopathic deformities I have ever run into! And the worst, the most dangerous of the bunch, is Maggott. You've got one religious maniac, one malignant dwarf, two near-idiots... and the rest I don't even wanna think about!
Well, I can't think of a better way to fight a war.
These people don't know their enemy is the Germans. They think the enemy is their own United States Army!
Maybe that's because the Germans haven't done anything to them yet.
Hey! What's the matter with you? You think I want to die? Ha! If you think that then you don't know Victor Franko.
Any questions?
Suh? Do we have to eat with niggahs?
[Jefferson jumps Maggot]
What's going on, sir?
Oh, the gentleman from the South had a question about the dining arrangements. He and his comrades are discussing place settings now.

[impersonating a General]
Where are you from, son?
Madison City, Missouri, sir!
Never heard of it.
I reckon the folks'd be a sight happier if I died like a soldier. Can't say I would.
Killin' generals could get to be a habit with me.
You've seen a general inspecting troops before haven't you? Just walk slow, act dumb and look stupid!

[impersonating a general]
Very pretty, Colonel, Very pretty, But, can they fight?

1. Down to the road block, we've just begun 2. The guards are through 3. The Major's men are on a spree 4. Major and Wladislaw go through the door 5. Pinkley stays out in the drive 6. The Major gives the rope a fix 7. Wladislaw throws the hook to heaven 8. Jimenez has got a date 9. The other guys go up the line 10. Sawyer and Lever are in the pen 11. Posey guards points five and seven 12. Wladislaw and the Major go down to delve 13. Franko goes up without being seen 14. Zero-hour - Jimenez cuts the cable, Franko cuts the phone 15. Franko goes in where the others have been 16. We all come out like it's Halloween.
Which one of you guys wants to be a general?
[to Pinkley]
Pinkley?
What kind of general, sir?
Just a plain, ordinary, every day, home-lovin' American general.
I'd rather be a civilian, sir.
I never went in for embroidery, just results.

[briefing the dozen]
And kill any officer in sight.
Ours or theirs?
I wish I could read this. I think it's dirty.
And where is Donald Duck?
Donald Duck's down at the crossroads with a machine gun.
He'd better not be asleep or we all be in trouble, huh!
How come you speak German?
My old man came from Silesia. He didn't speak German, he didn't dig coal. If he didn't dig coal, he didn't eat.
What do you think, Sergeant?
I think you'll do just fine, sir.

[emphatically]
Don't give me that! I said what do you think?
I think the first chance one of those lovers gets, he's going to shoot the Major right in the head... sir.
This war was *not* started for your private gratification, and you can be damned sure it's not being run for your personal convenience, either!
It's judgment day, sinners! Come out, come out wherever you are!

[while the dozen are cavorting with the prostitutes in the guards' barracks]
I wonder if any of them even know it's Mother's Day.

[glances at Kinder and pauses briefly]
is it?

[Sergeant Bowren is introducing the prisoners for Major Reisman]
Franko, V.R.; death by hanging. Vladek, M.; thirty years hard labor. Jefferson, R. T.; death by hanging. Pinkley, V.L.; thirty years imprisonment. Gilpin, S.; thirty years hard labor. Posey, S.; death by hanging. Wladislaw, T.; death by hanging. Sawyer, S. K.; twenty years hard labor. Lever, R.; twenty years imprisonment. Bravos, T.R.; twenty years hard labor. Jiminez, J.P.; twenty years hard labor. Maggott, A.J.; death by hanging.
Reisman! Some people may consider you a first-class officer. But as far as I'm concerned, you're a disorganized, undisciplined clown. I'm gonna' make it my business to run you out of this Army.
I owe you an apology, colonel. I always thought that you were a cold, unimaginative, tight-lipped officer. But you're really quite emotional, aren't you?
Posey, what did they lock you up for? I mean, what did you do?
I already told you that sir.
Well tell me again. I'm sure your friends over here would like to know too.
This fella kept pushing me. I don't like t be pushed so I hit him.
Killed a man with your bare hands because he shoved you?
I only hit him once.
Only him him once. And drove his jawbone right through his brain because he pushed him.
Boy, do I love that Franko.
I don't want to hurt you Major.
You're not gonna hurt me, I'm gonna hurt you.
What's your name, soldier?
Number two, Sir!
You know what to do, free the French and shoot the Germans!

I take it you don't deny your responsibility for the fact that on the night of April 14/15, a military establishment of the United States Army was the scene of a drunken party! At which no less than seven female civilians took an active part!

[deadpan]
Oh yes, sir, they took an active part.
[Gen. Worden muffles a laugh]
You only hit him once?
I didn't mean to kill him!

[after going through the 16 steps of the mission on the plane, someone says Seventeen]
Seventeen. D-day. We get out as best we can and make our way to the coast. And hope that the entire invasion hasn't been a total disaster. Otherwise, we got a long swim home.
